title: 114_s2182
content: The "Cut, Cap, and Balance Act of 2015" is also known as the "Cut" Act. It amends the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 by adding spending limits. The "Cut, Cap, and Balance Act of 2015" sets spending limits for fiscal year 2016 in the House of Representatives and the Senate. Adjustments can be made for the global war on terrorism. The "Cut, Cap, and Balance Act of 2015" establishes spending limits for fiscal year 2016 in the House and Senate, with provisions for adjustments related to the global war on terrorism. The "Cut, Cap, and Balance Act of 2015" sets spending limits for fiscal year 2016 in Congress, with exemptions for certain functions like Social Security, Medicare, Veterans Benefits, Net Interest, and Military personnel accounts. It also includes statutory enforcement of spending caps through sequestration. The sequesters for discretionary and direct spending implementation under the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 are detailed, with exemptions for specific categories like military personnel accounts, TRICARE for Life, Medicare, Social Security, veterans, and net interest. Presidential order modifications are also addressed. The sequesters for discretionary and direct spending under the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 exempt specific categories like military retirement, Social Security, veterans, and net interest. Modifications to the Presidential order are also discussed. The Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 exempts certain categories from sequestration, such as military retirement, Social Security, veterans, and net interest. Any bill altering a sequestration order must achieve the same reductions in new budget authority and outlays for the applicable fiscal year as specified in the order. Title II of the Act amends definitions related to total spending limits, including the term GDP. Additionally, Title III is amended to enforce GDP outlay limits. Title III of the Act enforces GDP outlay limits, which are determined based on projected GDP for each fiscal year as estimated by the Director of the Office of Management and Budget. The limits range from 19.9 percent for fiscal year 2016 to 18 percent for fiscal years 2021 to 2025. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget establishes the GDP outlay limit for the budget year in the President's budget, which includes all federal outlays. The Office of Management and Budget establishes the GDP outlay limit for the budget year in the President's budget. Total federal outlays include all on-budget and off-budget outlays. Sequestration to enforce this section is implemented according to the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985. Certain programs are exempt from this section. Title III of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include enforcement procedures that prevent bills, resolutions, or amendments from exceeding the current GDP outlay limits. This amendment aims to maintain spending within set limits to ensure a balanced budget. SEC. 301 of Title III requires a balanced budget amendment to be submitted to states, with provisions including limiting total outlays, setting spending limits as a percentage of GDP, and requiring a \2/3\ vote in Congress for tax increases. It also prohibits any legislation allowing additional borrowing until the balanced budget amendment is transmitted to the states.
